is a service town on the Hume Highway in Southern
best known for the decommissioned submarine that stands next to the highway in the centre of the town.
now bypasses Holbrook, roughly half way between the two.  The town is still a good stopping point with fuel, food, toilets, and visitor attractions.

.  You walk on it, have a barbecue, or have coffee at cafe next to it.  There are some interpretive signs.  Admission is free, and is a good alternative stopping place to the bland fast food restaurants or highway services.

content=The National Museum of Australian Pottery has an extensive collection of 19th and early 20th century Australian domestic pottery from over 120 Australian pottery companies established between European settlement and the end of World War I, (1918).

:Studio Ceramics 1954 - 1957. Exhibition runs from 1st September 2013 until the 23rd February 2014

value: directions=in the main street, opposite the National Museum of Australian Pottery
price=$5.00 for adults, $3.00 concessions and $1.00 for children.

content=The Woolpack Inn Museum is a two story heritage listed historic building. It has 22 rooms showing19th century include bedrooms, dining room, sitting room, kitchen, pantry and laundry, and a number of other rooms filled with historic items. In the grounds is a c. 1872 drop slab school house, a replica of the old Holbrook bakery, a black smithâ€™s shop and a large collection of old machinery, wagons and coaches.
There are some craft stores along the Hume.

There are two bakeries in town.
